bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to John Holloway, 1717 December 9

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to his attorney John Holloway, December 9, 1717, concerning claims by Edmund Jenings that Carter had placed a fence on his property. Carter states that his fence is in the same place as the land's former owner, Mrs. Whaley, had had her fence, but if Jenings can convince him that the fence is misplaced, he will acknowledge it. He continues that the serious injury to his right wrist will probably prevent his attendance at the next session of the Assembly which he understands is to meet in March. The writ against the Lees has been received and he will make use of it if the occasion arises. Some of Carter's comments about a proposal by Holloway for "an equal distribution of Mr. Lee's debts among his creditors" have been omitted by the copyist, and Carter concludes by thanking Holloway for his services.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to John Holloway, December 9, 1717

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
Decembr 9th 1717.
To John Holloway

div1.p:
I give you my kind thanks
for your two late letters.

As for Collo Jennings' pretentions
of my pails standing upon his land
it is a thing purely novel to me. If
I mistake not, they stand on the
same place where the former pails
did which he himself was the
seller of to Mrs. Whaley: and why I
must not hold the same ground that she
did I can see no reason.

Our Assembly it seems is to sit
down early in March. At this
time my right arm, altho' almost
six weeks ago hurt, continues very
useless to me. Some of the bones of
my wrist are displaced and my hand
quite distorted in so much that I can
neither dress nor undress myself. So that
I fear I shall not be able to venture
to lie out of my own bed this winter.
what time of the Assembly I may
be at under my present circumstances
I cannot foretell; but whenever
Collo Jennings and I meet, if he
can convince me that my enclosure
is upon any of his land, reason will
oblige me to make a proper acknow
=ledgement to him.

I received the writ against the
Lees and shall make use of it as
occasion is given.

Your other proposal about an
equal distribution of Mr. Lee's debt
among his creditors X X
X X X X X X

I never was one of those who were
for starving their causes; and you
are so strenuous & diligent in suppor
=ting those you undertake, I shall
always be desirous of depending upon
your abilities as often as I have oc
=casion.

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Minor- Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia. These texts are all nineteenth-century copies. Apparently there was in existence a letter book of Robert Carter's—now lost—from which the unknown copiest recorded these texts. As they are the only texts, the punctuation and "corrections" obviously supplied by the copiest have been retained. The copyist used a series of the letter "x" to indicate omission of material that he did not copy.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The return address, county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded letter.

[2] This may be Mary Page Whaley (d. 1742), wife of James Whaley (d. 1701). The Whaleys and Edmund Jenings lived in York County. (See Lyon G. Tyler, "Grammar and Mattey Practice and Model School," William and Mary Quarterly. 1st ser., 4(1895- 1896): 3-14.)
[3] This session of the Assembly did not meet until April 23, 1717.
[4] It is impossible to determine which "Mr. Lee" RC refers to here.
[5] The nineteenth-century copyist inserted "[property?]" after the word "debt."
